issues.description: The problem statement and UML refer to a class named `Stock`, but the template (and solution) uses `Inventory` instead of `Stock`. Students expecting to implement or extend `Stock` will not find it, causing confusion.
issues.suggested_fix: Either rename the `Inventory` class in the template (and solution) to `Stock`, or update the problem statement and UML to refer to `Inventory` consistently instead of `Stock`.

issues.description: The problem statement refers to a class named `Stock` (with methods add, take, findStockIngredient, addToStockIngredients, emptyStock), but both the template and solution define and use a class named `Inventory` for this functionality. This mismatch forces students to map the concept of “stock” in the exercise description to an `Inventory` class in code, adding unnecessary cognitive load.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the naming by renaming the `Inventory` class (and its references) in the template and solution to `Stock`, or update the problem statement to refer to `Inventory` instead of `Stock`.
